The use of mechanical restraint is prohibited in residential child care facilities, except as permitted in COMAR 14.31.07.08.
Program personnel are not prohibited from using a protective or stabilizing device prescribed by a health care professional.
The use of seclusion is prohibited in Maryland residential child care facilities.
Referral to Team.

If restraint is used, and the child’s behavior intervention plan does not include the use of restraint, the team specified in Regulation .17A of this chapter shall meet within 5 business days of the incident to consider:
The review of the safe environment plan;
The need for a functional behavioral assessment;
Reviewing or developing appropriate behavioral interventions; and
Revising or implementing a behavior intervention plan.
If a child’s behavior intervention plan includes the use of restraint, it shall specify how often the team shall meet to review or revise, as appropriate, the child’s behavior intervention plan.
When a team meets to review or revise a child’s behavior intervention plan, the team shall consider:
Existing health, physical, psychological, and psychosocial information;
Information provided by the parent or legal guardian and the custodial agency; and
Observations by program personnel and related service providers.

The program shall provide the parent or legal guardian, the child, the custodial agency, and the child’s attorney with written notice when a team proposes or refuses to initiate or change the child’s behavior intervention plan to include the use of restraint.

A parent or legal guardian or child may request an appeal through the program's grievance process in accordance with Regulation .09E of this chapter if the parent or legal guardian or child disagrees with the team’s decision to propose, or refuse to initiate, or change the child’s behavior intervention plan to use restraint.
Documentation Requirements for the Use of Restraint. Documentation of events surrounding the utilization of restraint in the child’s record shall include, but not be limited to:
Type of restraint used;
Rationale for the restraint and expected outcome of the intervention;
The safe environment plan or other less restrictive interventions, de-escalation techniques, or all of these utilized prior to the implementation of restraint and the child’s response to each;
The child’s response during and after the implementation of the restraint;
The length of time in restraint;
Description of the specific precipitating factors leading to the restraint, including:
Description of observable behavioral, emotional, and physical characteristics of the child involved;
Degree of restriction or loss of privileges;
Any event, situation, or condition immediately preceding the behavior that prompted the use of restraint; and
The behavior that prompted the use of a restraint;
Specific location where the restraint occurred, and general activity occurring within the environment before the incident;
Staffing level, types of program personnel (male, female, unlicensed, licensed);
Unit capacity and unit population;
The names of the program personnel who observed the behavior that prompted the use of restraint;
The names and signatures of the program personnel implementing, observing, and monitoring the use of restraint;
A description of the restraint event, including:
The child’s behavior and reaction during the restraint; and
The name and signature of the administrator informed of the use of restraint;
Physical condition, including any observable or reportable injuries of the child during and after the restraint, including:
Description of any injuries sustained;
On-site first aid intervention; and
Off-site medical treatment;
Medication, as identified in the child’s safe environment plan, administered before, during, or after the restraint;
Date and time of the restraint; and
Notification:
To the program administrator or designee;
To the parent or legal guardian;
To the placement agency; and
To the licensing agency in writing, the information described in Regulation .18D of this chapter.
Debriefing.
Staff.

Within 24 hours of the incident, program personnel involved in the incident and the clinical coordinator, supervisor, or designee shall discuss and document the management of the incident by addressing the following:
The precipitating factors of the incident;
Program personnel response to the incident;
De-escalation techniques or less restrictive interventions attempted, or both, and the child’s response to each;
Timeliness of program personnel intervention;
Program personnel's ability to function as a team and improvements that could be made;
Adequacy of program personnel response and need for additional staff;
Aspects of the incident that should be the focus for discussion for the team; and
Other interventions that could have been used to prevent the restraint.
Child.

Within 24 hours of the incident, unless contraindicated by the safe environment plan, the child involved in the incident and the program administrator or designee shall discuss and document the management of the incident by addressing the following:
The precipitating factors of the incident;
Program personnel response to the incident;
De-escalation techniques or less restrictive interventions attempted, or both, and the child’s response to each;
Timeliness of program personnel intervention;
Program personnel's ability to function as a team, and improvements that could be made;
Adequacy of program personnel response, and need for additional staff;
Aspects of the incident that should be the focus for discussion for the team; and
Other interventions that could have been used to prevent the restraint.
If the child declines to participate in the debriefing:
Program personnel shall document efforts to conduct the debriefing, efforts to engage the child in the process, and the reasons the child declined to participate; and
Negative consequences may not be imposed upon the child for nonparticipation.
Administrative Procedures.
Each residential child care facility shall develop policies and procedures to address:
A continuum of prevention and intervention strategies that incorporate the principles of positive behavioral interventions, strategies and supports, and trauma-informed care;
The prevention of self-injurious behaviors;
Methods for identifying and defusing potentially dangerous behavior;
The use and documentation of time-out consistent with Regulation .15D of this chapter; and
The use of restraint consistent with Regulation .15E of this chapter.
Quality Assurance. Each residential child care facility shall develop a quality assurance process to:
Ensure that each child’s needs are addressed;
Monitor and address the incident management findings, frequency, and types of restraints utilized;
Implement measures to reduce the use of restraint; and
Annually review policies and procedures, and provide them to program personnel and the parent or legal guardian.
Training.

Each residential child care facility shall provide training to program personnel on this chapter and the appropriate implementation of policies and procedures developed in accordance with §A of this regulation.

The program personnel shall receive training on current professionally accepted practices and standards from a vendor whose training program has been approved by the State and which includes all of the following:
Positive behavioral intervention strategies and supports;
Trauma-informed care; and
Restraint.
Training shall be required:
Before program personnel may work with children independently; and
At least annually.
Each residential child care facility shall identify program personnel authorized to serve as a program wide resource to:
Assist with training on de-escalation techniques; and
Ensure proper administration of time out and restraint.
Monitoring and Compliance.
Each residential child care facility shall develop policies and procedures on:
Monitoring the use of time out and restraint; and
Receiving and investigating complaints regarding time out and restraint practices.
The residential child care facility shall report the use of restraint to:
The parent or legal guardian within 24 hours of the incident unless otherwise specified in the safe environment plan by the parent or legal guardian;
The placement agency;
The licensing agency in writing, information described in Regulation .18D of this chapter; and
Child Protective Services, as required by Regulation .14 of this chapter.
The licensing agency may monitor and request any information regarding any matter related to time-out or restraint implemented by a residential child care facility.
Written Policy. The licensee shall have and follow a written policy to govern its actions when a child is discovered to be absent without leave.

Child’s Return. Unless otherwise specified in the child’s individual plan of care, if the child has not returned to the program within 1 hour of the program discovering that the child is missing or unaccounted for, the licensee shall notify:
The local law enforcement authority;
The placing agency;
The licensing agency; and
The child’s parent or legal guardian, unless inconsistent with the child’s individual plan of care.
Notification. When a child who was missing or unaccounted for returns to the program, the licensee shall immediately notify:
The local law enforcement authority;
The child’s parent or legal guardian;
The placing agency; and
The licensing agency.

section.heading: Admission, Individual Plan of Care, Behavior Intervention Plan, and Discharge.

para.text: General Requirements.
The licensee shall have and follow written policies regarding:
Admission;
Individual plan of care;
Behavior intervention plan;
Behavior support services; and
Discharge.
The licensee shall form a team comprised of at least the following individuals to participate in the:
Admission process:
A representative designated by the placing agency;
Program staff responsible for the care and supervision of the child;
Unless clearly inappropriate, the child; and
If appropriate, the child’s parent or legal guardian; and
Development of the individual plan of care and the discharge plan:
A representative designated by the placing agency;
A human service professional from the program considering the admission;
Program staff responsible for the care and supervision of the child;
The child’s parent or legal guardian, if consistent with the child’s permanency plan; and
Unless clearly inappropriate, the child.
Each team shall:
Document those present and participating; and
Indicate in the individual case record the reason, if known, why an invited individual did not attend.
Admission.
The licensee shall include in its admission policy a:
Statement of nondiscrimination consistent with Title VII of the Civil Rights Act and State Government Article, Title 20, Annotated Code of Maryland;
Provision for an assessment to determine the child’s needs and the licensee’s ability to meet them; and
Method for notifying, when appropriate, a child’s parent or legal guardian if the child is self-admitted.
The licensee may not admit a child referred by an out-of-State placing agency without documentation that the agency has initiated actions to abide by any applicable interstate compact.
The licensee may not admit into care:
More children than the number specified in its license;
Children outside of the age range specified in the license; or
Children not of the gender specified in the license.
In order to admit a child whose characteristics and needs do not fit the profile approved by the licensing agency, the licensee shall document that it has:
Obtained oral permission from the licensing agency before the child's admission; and
Requested written documentation of the licensing agency’s permission within 5 days of the child’s placement, which describes:
The reasons for the placement; and
How the program will ensure adequate and appropriate care for the child.
Except for emergency placements, the licensee shall admit a child only upon receipt of at least:
A social history or predisposition report, to include any history of abuse or neglect;
A health history that is not older than 6 months, including, if applicable, a list of currently prescribed medications;
A mental health screening report that:
Includes screening for the child's risk of suicide; and
Was completed in less than 72 hours before the child's placement;
An educational history;
Medical insurance documentation;
If required by federal or State law, any psychological, psychiatric, or developmental assessment that is not older than 12 months;
Emergency telephone numbers to contact the child’s parent or legal guardian;
If applicable, a document that specifies a guardian or custodian of the child other than the biological parent;
The child's permanency plan;
Authorizations necessary for providing care, including:
Medical, dental, and behavioral health authorizations for routine and emergency care;
Any applicable court order or master's recommendation; and
Applicable non-court order for shelter care.

For emergency placements, the licensee and the placing agency shall ensure that the licensee receives the documents specified in §§A, B, and C of this regulation within 24 hours of the child's placement.

If it has the discretion to refuse to admit a child referred by the placing agency, the licensee shall process each referral promptly and submit to the placing agency its decision on the referral within 10 days after receipt.
The licensee shall:
Examine each child upon admission;
Document in the child's individual case record any illness, fever, rash, bruise, or injury; and
Take appropriate action as necessary.
Within 3 days after admission, the licensee shall include in a child’s individual case record:
A preliminary, individualized assessment of the child’s needs performed by a human service professional;
A safe environment plan; and
Any document listed in §B(4) of this regulation not received before the child’s placement.
Individual Plan of Care. The licensee shall require the team convened pursuant to §A(2)(b) of this regulation:
To develop for each child, within 30 days after admission, an individual plan of care that includes:
An evaluation that meets the requirements of the Early and Periodic Screening, Diagnosis and Treatment program;
If appropriate, a behavior intervention plan as defined in §D of this regulation;
Measurable objectives with time frames leading to the achievement of goals;
Implementation dates and strategies;
Individuals responsible for providing the supports, services, implementation, and monitoring of the plan;
Documentation indicating whether or not the child and parent or legal guardian agree with the plan;
Education, including special education and related services to implement the individualized education program of a student as required under the Individuals With Disabilities Education Act;
Family relationship;
Health care;
Life skills development;
Personal, emotional, and social development;
Recreation plan;
Vocational training;
The placing agency’s permanency plan; and
Other areas as appropriate; and
To execute the:
Review and update of every child’s individual plan of care at least every 90 days;
Modification of the individual plan of care as required by the child’s needs, interests, and circumstances; and
Documentation of monthly progress toward achievement of goals and estimated length of stay.
Behavior Plan.
The licensee shall have a comprehensive written policy that identifies the process by which a behavior intervention plan is determined to be appropriate.
The licensee shall ensure that a behavior intervention plan is developed for each child for whom it is appropriate that includes:
An assessment of each challenging behavior as identified in the individual plan of care;
A description of the function of current behaviors including their frequency and severity;
The behavioral objectives for the child including:
Criteria for determining achievement of the objectives established;
A description of the adaptive skills to be learned by a child that serve as alternatives to behaviors that present a danger to self or serious bodily harm to others;
A description of the adaptive skills to be learned by a child that serve as functional alternatives to the challenging behavior or behaviors to be decreased;
Identification of the individual or individuals responsible for monitoring the behavior intervention plan;
The data to be collected to assess progress towards meeting the behavior intervention plan’s objectives;
Documentation for the use of physical restraint, the reason for its use, and the length of time used; and
For licensees of the Maryland Department of Health, documentation for the use of mechanical restraint, the reason for its use, and the length of time used;
Take into account the medical condition of the child; and
Describe the treatment techniques and when the techniques are to be used.
Before implementation, the licensee shall ensure that each behavior intervention plan that includes the use of restraints includes the written informed consent of:
The child, when appropriate;
The child’s parent or legal guardian, when appropriate; and
The placing agency’s designee.

If the program is licensed to serve children with developmental disabilities, each behavior intervention plan that includes the use of restraints shall be approved by the standing committee established under COMAR 14.31.07.08 before the plan’s implementation.
Behavior Support Services.
A licensee who contracts for behavior support services as determined by the behavior intervention plan shall ensure that its contractor:
Meets the requirements of this chapter; and
Is knowledgeable about the licensing agency's service delivery system.
Behavior support services may include:
Behavioral consultation;
Temporary augmentation of staff;
Behavioral training; and
Behavioral respite services.

In addition to the training requirements in COMAR 10.22.02.10—.11 for licensees of the Maryland Department of Health and the training and requirements of this chapter, the licensee shall ensure that staff who provide behavior support services, before being assigned independent duties, receive training in the:
Principles of behavioral change; and
Use of a specific behavior management technique as outlined in the child’s behavior intervention plan.
Discharge.
For planned discharges, the licensee shall:
Except for emergency shelter placement, and at least 30 days before a planned discharge, prepare a discharge plan which includes:
The name, address, telephone number, and relationship of the individual with whom the child will be residing upon discharge;

A statement of unmet identified and continuing needs including but not limited to behavioral and somatic health, education, family and peer relationships, employment, behavior, medications, and recommendation for follow-up treatment; and
Within 30 calendar days after discharge, submit to the placing agency a discharge summary which includes:
A final summary of the child’s performance in the program;
A summary of the child’s health, dental, optical, and behavioral health records; and

A summary of services provided to the child, including behavioral and somatic health, education, family and peer relationships, employment, behavior, medications, and recommendation for follow-up treatment.
For unplanned discharges, the licensee shall:
Provide at least 72 hours’ notice to the placing agency unless there is imminent risk of harm to self or others;
At the time of discharge, provide to the placement agency a discharge plan which includes:
Specific details of the reason for discharge; and
A statement of unmet and continuing needs; and
Within 30 calendar days after discharge, submit to the placing agency a discharge summary which includes:
A final summary of the child’s performance in the program;
A final summary of the child’s medical, dental, optical, and behavioral health records; and
A summary of services provided to the child.
General Requirements. The licensee shall:
Submit reports and maintain records as directed by the licensing and contracting agencies in order to ensure compliance with these regulations and other federal and State laws; and
Comply with requirements for incident reporting as specified by the licensing and contracting agencies.
Confidentiality of Records. The licensee shall:
Have and follow written procedures for the maintenance and security of individual case records and health records in accordance with State and federal law, which include:
The identity of the staff persons responsible for the custody and maintenance of the records;
A prohibition on the release of records except in accordance with law or contractual obligation; and
A notice that employees may not disclose or knowingly permit the disclosure of any information concerning the child or the child’s family to any unauthorized person;
Destroy records, in accordance with timelines established by State and federal law, in a manner that will preserve their confidentiality; and
Ensure that if the program’s parent corporation dissolves, its individual case records concerning children served by the program are given to the placing agency.
Record Maintenance. The licensee shall:
Maintain a register of the children currently in the program which includes the child's:
Name;
Sex;
Date of birth;
Placing agency; and
Dates of admission and anticipated discharge;
Retain for the later of 5 years after discharge of a child, or 3 years after the child becomes 18 years old, individual case records;
Retain financial records for at least 6 years from the date of their creation or after any contract with the State terminates; and
Protect all documents against fire damage, theft, and unauthorized disclosure.

section.heading: Program Planning, Evaluation, and Quality Improvement.

para.text: Program Planning and Evaluation. The licensee shall have a formal process for program planning and evaluation which includes at least:
A clearly stated written mission for the program approved by the board of directors;
A set of measurable goals and objectives which is based upon the mission, program, population served, and State-mandated outcome measures;
A periodic review of achievement of goals and objectives; and
A correction plan approved by the Board for unmet goals.
Program Quality Improvement. The licensee shall:
Develop and implement an ongoing quality improvement plan; and
Annually review and evaluate the quality and effectiveness of the services provided.
